subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Unicode proposal again.
msgSnippet: ... Yes. ... Yes, it has them, but that is the wrong thing.  The standard way to prevent ligaturing is to use the character U+200D, ZERO WIDTH NON-JOINER,
messageBody:
amd64_hacker scripsit:

> I do think we should have a semi-official/standard way of overriding the
> choices the rendering layer makes though.

Yes.

> Luckily Unicode already has just the thing - Variant Selectors.

Yes, it has them, but that is the wrong thing. The standard way to
prevent ligaturing is to use the character U+200D, ZERO WIDTH NON-JOINER,
between the characters not to be ligatured. Contrariwise, ligaturing
may be promoted (it can never be forced, because if the font has no
ligature glyph you are out of luck) using U+200C, ZERO WIDTH JOINER.

For a Latin-font example, you could prevent "fi" from being ligatured
even in a font that supported automatic ligaturing using f+ZWNJ+i;
but if you wanted "ct" to be ligatured, you could invoke it using c+ZWJ+t.

--
